message_1: Consider the metric space (ℝ,d) where d is the standard metric. Let S = {1/n | n ∈ ℕ}. Is S a compact set in (ℝ,d)? Prove or disprove using the definition of compactness.
message_2:
To prove or disprove whether S is a compact set in (ℝ, d), we will use the definition of compactness. A set is compact if every open cover of the set has a finite subcover.

Let's consider an open cover of S. For each 1/n ∈ S, let U_n = (1/(n+1), 1/(n-1)) be an open interval containing 1/n. Note that 1/(n-1) is undefined for n = 1, so we can replace it with 2 for U_1 = (1/2, 2). Now, we have an open cover {U_n} for S.

However, there is no finite subcover of {U_n} that covers S. To see this, suppose there exists a finite subcover {U_{n1}, U_{n2}, ..., U_{nk}}. Let N = max{n1, n2, ..., nk}. Then, for any m > N, 1/m is not covered by any of the intervals U_{ni} because 1/m < 1/(N+1), and 1/(N+1) is the left endpoint of U_N, which is the largest interval in the finite subcover.

Since we have found an open cover of S with no finite subcover, S is not a compact set in (ℝ, d).
